questions.text: A 28 year old woman undergoes an illegal abortion and is rushed to the emergency department after collapsing at home. On arrival, she is unresponsive and later dies. Upon forensic examination, the immediate cause of death is determined. Which of the following is NOT typically considered an immediate cause of death in cases of criminal abortion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Septicemia

Explanation:

While septicemia is a common complication in criminal abortions, it usually takes time to develop and is considered a delayed cause of death rather than an immediate cause of death.

Immediate cause

Delayed cause (onset within 48 hrs to 72 hrs)

Remote cause

1) Vagal inhibition

2) Air embolism

3) Hemorrhage

4) Fat embolism

5) Amniotic fluid embolism

6) Rarely poisoning.

1) Septicemia

2) Pyaemia

3) Confined local infection and toxemia

4) General peritonitis

5) Tetanus.

1) Jaundice and renal failure

2) Bacterial endocarditis

3) Pulmonary embolism.
  • Fat embolism (Option A): Fat embolism can occur during illegal abortions, especially if bones are fractured or fatty tissues are disturbed, leading to embolic events.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism (Option C): Although rare, amniotic fluid embolism can be a cause of sudden death in both criminal and legal abortions, particularly if the uterine wall is breached.
  • Vagal inhibition (Option D): Vagal inhibition, due to sudden pain or manipulation, can lead to reflex cardiac arrest, an immediate cause of death in such cases.

questions.text: Which of the following acts cannot be considered as rape?

choices.text: Inserting an article into the urethra
Manipulating any part of a woman’s body to cause penetration

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Penetrating wife without consent

Explanation:

In India, sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (old definition not under 15 years) is not considered as rape.

Rape:

BNS

BNS 63 (Old: Section 375 IPC)

Definition

Unlawful sexual intercourse by a man with a woman through force or under certain conditions

Acts considered

  • Penetrates his penis into the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus
  • Inserts any object or body part (not his penis) or applies his mouth to the vagina, mouth, urethra, or anus (Option A ruled out) (Option D ruled out)
  • Manipulates any part of the woman's body to cause penetration into the vagina, urethra, or anus (Option B ruled out)

Circumstances

  • Against her will
  • Without her consent
  • With her consent obtained through fear of death or hurt
  • With her consent, when she believes he is her husband due to impersonation
  • When she cannot understand the nature of consent due to unsoundness of mind, intoxication, or being drugged
  • Statutory rape: With or without her consent, if she is under 18 years of age
  • When she is unable to communicate consent

Exception

  • Medical interventions or procedures
  • Sexual intercourse by a man with his wife if she is not under 18 years of age (Option C)

questions.text: A 32 year old man gets into an argument and intentionally causes severe injuries to another person, resulting in a broken arm and significant physical pain. The police decided to charge him under the appropriate section of the BNS. Which section of the BNS is appropriate in this context?

choices.text: He is charged under the section BNS 115 (1)
He is charged under the section BNS 115 (2)
He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)
He is charged under the section BNS 124 (2)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) He is charged under the section BNS 117 (2)

Explanation:

  • BNS 117 (2):
    • Specifies the punishment for voluntarily causing grievous hurt, which can result in imprisonment for up to seven years and a fine. (Option C)
    • Old: Section 325 IPC
  • BNS 115 (1):
    • Defines voluntarily causing hurt. (Option A ruled out)
    • Old: Section 321 IPC
  • BNS 115 (2):
    • Deals with the punishment for voluntarily causing hurt, which carries a lesser penalty than grievous hurt, with imprisonment up to one year or a fine of up to ₹1,0000. (Option B ruled out)
    • Old: Section 323 IPC, where fine was up to ₹1000.
  • BNS 124 (2):
    • Covers voluntarily throwing or attempting to throw acid, with a minimum imprisonment of 5 years and a fine. (Option D ruled out)
    • Old: Section 326B IPC

questions.text: A 35 year old man was assaulted, leading to several injuries and is hospitalized. You are tasked with determining whether the case fits the legal classification of grievous hurt under BNS 116 for some of the expected events. Which of the following scenarios would NOT be classified as grievous hurt?

choices.text: The person dies due to an injury that, under normal circumstances, was not intended to cause death.
The person suffers an abdominal injury causing the intestines to protrude and is hospitalized for 22 days.
The person sustains a deep injury without any fracture or permanent disfigurement.
The person is in a coma for 20 days following a severe head injury.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) The person dies due to an injury that, under normal circumstances, was not intended to cause death.

Explanation:

This situation involves an unintended fatal outcome, which falls under the category of culpable homicide or accidental death, not grievous hurt. Grievous hurt pertains to severe injuries, not necessarily causing death.

 

BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous:

  • Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury).
  • Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  • Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  • Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints
  • Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint.
  • Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  • Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth.
  • Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 20 days, in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine.

 

The person suffers an abdominal injury causing the intestines to protrude and is hospitalized for 22 days (Option B): This is classified as grievous hurt because it causes serious injury that can endanger life and requires significant medical intervention.

The person sustains a deep injury without any fracture or permanent disfigurement (Option C): A deep injury may cause considerable pain or disability, but without a fracture or permanent disfigurement, it does not meet the legal criteria for grievous hurt.

The person is in a coma for 20 days following a severe head injury (Option D): Prolonged unconsciousness or coma due to head injury is considered grievous hurt, as it severely affects the victim's capacity to follow ordinary pursuits.

questions.text: A 40 year old man was involved in an altercation and sustained multiple injuries. You are evaluating whether these injuries qualify as grievous hurt under BNS 116. Which of the following scenarios does NOT meet the criteria for classifying the injury as grievous hurt?

choices.text: He is rendered impotent after sustaining a serious genital injury.
He loses a single tooth due to a punch on his face
He attains a cut injury on his face that temporarily alters his appearance.
He got his wrist fractured due to a heavy fall

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) He attains a cut injury on his face that temporarily alters his appearance.

Explanation:

A temporary cut or injury that does not result in permanent disfigurement does not meet the criteria for grievous hurt.

 

BNS 116 (Old Section 320 IPC) defines following injuries as grievous:

  1. Emasculation (cutting off the penis, castration, or causing loss of power of erection due to spinal injury). (Option A ruled out)
  2. Permanent privation of the sight of either eye.
  3. Permanent privation of the hearing of either ear.
  4. Privation of any member (part, organ, limb) or joints
  5. Destruction or permanent impairing of powers of any member or joint.
  6. Permanent disfiguration of head or face.
  7. Fracture or dislocation of a bone or a tooth. (Options B and D ruled out)
  8. Any hurt which endangers life, or which causes the sufferer to be, during the space of 15 days, in severe bodily pain, or unable to follow his daily routine.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly defines the term "injury" as per legal terminology?

choices.text: Harm caused to a person’s reputation, body, or property, irrespective of legality.
Any harm legally or illegally caused to a person's mind, body, or property.
Any harm caused to a person's physical body.
Any harm illegally caused to a person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Any harm illegally caused to a person, in body, mind, reputation, or property.

Explanation:

 

IPC

Term

BNS

Definition

44

Injury

Sec 2(14)

The word "injury" denotes any harm illegally caused to any person, in body, mind, reputation, or property. (Option D)

45

Life

Sec 2(17)

The word "life" denotes the life of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

46

Death

Sec 2(6)

The word "death" denotes the death of a human being, unless the contrary appears from the context.

 

Harm caused to a person’s reputation, body, or property, irrespective of legality (Option A): The term "injury" specifically denotes illegal harm, not general harm regardless of legality.

Any harm legally or illegally caused to a person's mind, body, or property (Option B): Injury refers to illegal harm, not legal or illegal.

Any harm caused to a person's physical body (Option C): Injury encompasses more than just physical harm; it includes harm to mind, reputation, and property.

questions.text: A 11-year old child accused of murder was let go free after the trial. What could be the likely explanation in this case?

choices.text: BNS 20 - depending on the mental maturity
BNS 21 - depending on the mental maturity

questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) BNS 21 - depending on the mental maturity

Explanation:

BNS 21 deals with children between 7-12 years cannot be held liable if they lack sufficient maturity/understanding.

 

BNS 20 (Option B):

  • Child below 7 years of age will not be held criminally responsible for his/her act.
  • Minimum age of criminal responsibility:
    • 7 years (BNS)
    • 5 years (Indian Railways Act)
  • Minimum age of full criminal responsibility: 18 years

 

BNS 21 (Option C):

  • A child between 7-12 years of age can be held liable for any crime depending on their mental maturity.
  • Mental maturity is determined by the - Court of Law.

questions.text: A 60 year old man gets into a heated argument with his neighbor during a community event. In a fit of rage, he pushes the neighbour hard, causing him to fall and hit his head on a concrete surface. The neighbor sustains a severe head injury and dies a few hours later in the hospital. He did not intend to kill but was reckless during the confrontation. Which section of the BNS would he be most likely be charged under?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) BNS 105

Explanation:

BNS Section 105 applies because the act caused death, but without the intention to kill. The act was reckless and dangerous, leading to death, but it does not meet the criteria for murder under Section 103.

100 BNS: Culpable homicide

 

Culpable homicide not amounting to murder:

  • Defined under Section 105 of the BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA(BNS)
  • It refers to a situation where a person causes the death of another, but the act does not fulfill all the conditions necessary for it to be classified as murder under Section 101.
  • Death caused due to grave and sudden provocation.
  • Death caused without premeditation in the heat of the moment during a sudden fight.
  • Death caused in good faith while exercising the right to self-defense.

 

Punishment under Section 105 BNS:

The section is divided into two parts:

Part I:

  • If the act is done with the intention of causing death or causing bodily injury likely to cause death, the punishment can be life imprisonment or imprisonment for up to 10 years and a fine.

Part II:

  • If the act is done with the knowledge that it is likely to cause death but without any intention to cause death or such injury, the punishment can be imprisonment for up to 10 years or a fine, or both.

 

BNS 301 (Option A): Trespassing on burial places. Imprisonment for 1 year or fine and non-bailable.

BNS 104 (Option B): Punishment for murder by life convict.Punishment is death and non-bailable.

BNS 102 (Option D): Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than person whose death was intended.

questions.text: A surgeon deliberately administers a lethal dose of anesthesia to a patient during a routine surgery because of a personal grudge. The patient dies on the operating table. Investigations reveal that the surgeon was fully aware that the dose would cause death. Under which section of the BNS would the surgeon be charged?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) BNS 101

Explanation:

BNS Section 101 applies as the surgeon deliberately administered a lethal dose, knowing it would result in death. The act was intentional and premeditated, which qualifies as murder under this section.

BNS Section 100: Culpable homicide

Culpable homicide amounting to murder:

  • Defined under Section 101 of the BHARATIYA NYAYA SANHITA (BNS)
  • Intention to cause death: The person committing the act has the clear intention of causing the death of the victim.
  • Intention to cause bodily injury likely to cause death: The act is done with the intention of causing such bodily injury as the offender knows is likely to cause death.
  • Knowledge of high probability of death: The act is done with the knowledge that it is so imminently dangerous that it must, in all probability, cause death or such bodily injury as is likely to cause death.
  • The punishment for murder under Section 103 of the BNS is death or life imprisonment and the person may also be liable to pay a fine.

 

BNS 301 (Option A): Trespassing on burial places. Imprisonment for 1 year or fine and non-bailable.

BNS 302 (Option B): Uttering words with deliberate, intent to wound religious feelings. Imprisonment for 1 year or fine and non-bailable.

BNS 102 (Option D): Culpable homicide by causing death of person other than person whose death was intended.

questions.text: A 32 year old man, unaware that he is HIV positive, has been in a relationship with a woman for the past year. Neither he nor his partner has undergone recent medical check-ups, and they have been engaging in unprotected intercourse. Unfortunately, she tests positive for HIV as well. This act comes under which BNS?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) BNS Section 271

Explanation:

A man, unaware of his HIV-positive status, engages in unprotected intercourse with his partner. She contracts HIV.

Option Section Pertains To Applicability in Case
BNS 271 (Option A) Negligent act likely to spread infection Requires knowledge or reason to believe the act is likely to spread infection. Not applicable – he was unaware.
BNS 272 (Option B ruled out) Adulteration of food/drug Related to tampering with consumables. Not related.
BNS 106A (Option C ruled out) Organised crime/terror-related offences Not related to infectious disease or health violations. Not applicable.
BNS 109 (Option D ruled out) Abetment of an offence Secondary offence when someone aids/instigates a crime. Not primary here.

If the individual was truly unaware of his HIV status and had no reason to suspect infection, none of the sections listed apply directly.

However, if evidence later shows:

  • He had prior symptoms or risk factors,

  • Was advised to get tested,

  • Or had past risk exposure (e.g., unprotected sex, blood transfusion, drug use),

Then BNS Section 271 might be considered (i.e., negligent transmission, if he should have known).

Conclusion:

  • None of the options strictly apply if he was genuinely unaware of his status.

  • If one must be chosen based on legal proximity, then:

    Answer: A) BNS Section 271, only if there was reasonable belief or negligence in not getting tested.

questions.text: Person presented to ED with complaints of severe chest pain for 1 hour. CT chest done revealed the presence of Aortic dissection. Patient was taken up for an emergency endovascular surgery without obtaining consent as there were no caregivers present at the time of presentation. Patient succumbed to hypotensive shock during the procedure. The surgeon will not be held liable under
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) BNS 30

 

Explanation:

  • Aortic dissection is a surgical emergency without which the patient would die, and does not warrant an obtained consent under emergency circumstances and so the Surgeon will not be held liable for any unforeseen consequences during/after the procedure under BNS 30.
  • This is known as the Doctrine of Anticipation.

 

BNS related to consent:

BNS 25
  • Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age after rightful consent.

BNS 26 (Option A)
  • Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent.

BNS 27 (Option B)
  • Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person with unsound mind with guardian’s consent

BNS 28 (Option C)
  • Consent given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state is considered invalid.

BNS 30 (Option D)
  • An act done in good faith for the benefit of a person without their consent is not an offense.
  • This is true if the circumstances make it impossible for the person to give consent.
  • Known as Doctrine of Anticipation.

questions.text: BNS 27 deals with

choices.text: Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) with guardian’s consent
Act done in good faith for a person’s benefit after obtaining lawful consent
Act not intended to cause death/grievous hurt done by a person >18 years of age
Consent is not valid when it is given by fear/misconception

questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) with guardian’s consent

Explanation:

BNS 27 deals with the Act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person of unsound mind.

BNS related to consent:

BNS 25 (Option C)
  • Any act which causes harm except the act intended to cause death or grievous hurt is not an offense if it is done with the consent of a person who is above 18 years of age.
  • Consent can be either Implied (or) Expressed.
  • E.g., two boxers fighting each other in an olympic match.

BNS 26 (Option B)
  • If a person commits an act done in good faith and with the consent for the benefit of that person, it will not be considered an offense.
  • E.g., a surgeon performing surgery after getting consent.

BNS 27 (Option A)
  • Any act done in good faith for the benefit of a child (<12 years) or a person of unsound mind after obtaining guardian’s (caregiver’s) consent.
  • Neither the Doer nor the Caregiver would be held responsible for any unforeseen consequences.
  • E.g., a doctor doing necessary medical examination on a child (<12years) after obtaining guardian’s consent.

BNS 28 (Option D)
  • Consent is not valid if it is given by a person under fear or threat/under misconception of fact/child under 12 years of age/person of unsound mind/under intoxicated state.
  • E.g., a female giving consent for sex to her boss under fear of losing her job is considered invalid.

questions.text: Husband physically assaults his wife following a verbal altercation between them. On enquiry, it is known that the Husband was under the influence of alcohol during this act and his wife reveals that he is a chronic alcoholic, drinks on a daily basis. Which section deals with the liable act done by her husband?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) BNS 24

Explanation:

Her husband would be held liable under BNS 24 - deals with voluntary intoxication (as there is no history of the husband being forced to drink).

 

BNS dealing with Criminal liability:

BNS 20 (Option A)

Act done by a child below 7 years of age - NOT held liable

BNS 21

Act done by a child between 7-12 years of age can/cannot be held liable depending on the mental maturity (assessed by The court of law)

BNS 22 (Option B)

Act of a person of unsound mind/insane - NOT held liable (McNaughten’s rule)

BNS 23 (Option C)

Act of a person done under involuntary intoxication - NOT held liable

BNS 24 (Option D)

Act of a person done under voluntary intoxication - Held liable
